Award.AwardTitle: Instructional leadership for scientific practices: Resources for principals in evaluating and supporting teachers' science instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although K-8 principals are responsible for instructional improvement across all subject areas, their focus has traditionally been on literacy and mathematics and only occasionally on science content and practice. New standards and assessments in science require that principals and other instructional leaders provide significant support to teachers to help them successfully integrate scientific practices into their instruction. There is evidence that these instructional leaders often lack the knowledge, resources or skills to provide this support. This project will research the knowledge and supervision skills principals' and other instructional leaders' need to support teachers in successfully integrating scientific practices into their instruction, and develop innovative resources to support these leaders with a particular focus on high-minority, urban schools. The project will contribute to the emerging but limited literature on instructional leadership in science at the K-8 school level.

The resources developed will involve: (1) Introducing scientific practices (including rationales, descriptions and vignettes illustrating each of the 8 scientific practices); (2) Using tools in schools (providing an observation protocol, teacher feedback form and improvement planning template); and (3) Analyzing sample video (including links to video of K-8 science instruction, completed supervision tools, explanations of their coding, and discussion of how to use them with teachers). The project will conduct in-depth interviews with four principals, work with 25 principals in the Boston Public Schools to iteratively design and test the resources. The project will also develop a measure of Leadership Content Knowledge of Scientific Practices (LCK-SP) which will be used to assess principals' knowledge. The project's research component will: (1) investigate principals' current knowledge about scientific practices and methods for supervision of science instruction; and (2) examine how resources can be designed to support instructional leaders' content knowledge of scientific practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ILSP project focused on K-8 school principals and their supervision of science practices. Our initial goal was to develop an understanding of K-8 principals’ vision of science instruction and the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Toward that end, we conducted 26 interviews with a range of K-8 principals about their experiences and expertise supervising science instruction. We learned that principals’ understandings of science did not tend to include conceptualizations of science practices in the classroom (McNeill, Lowenhaupt & Katsh-Singer, 2018). Instead, principals focused feedback on general pedagogy, such as the number of students talking in class, rather than science specific features (Lowenhaupt & McNeill, 2017). Furthermore, when they did discuss the science practices, they more frequently discussed the investigating practices (e.g. planning and carrying out investigations), than the sensemaking practices (e.g. developing or using models) or critiquing practices (e.g. engaging in argument from evidence) (McNeill, Lowenhaupt & Katsh-Singer, 2018).


Using this information, we developed a set of ILSP resources designed to support principals in observing and providing feedback to their teachers, freely available online at: www.sciencepracticesleadership.com.These resources  include:

  • The Science Practices Continuum is intended for teachers and administrators to use in guiding and evaluating science practice-based instruction. For each science practice, the Continuum illustrates different levels of instruction. The goal is to highlight key levers for each practice to help instruction move farther along the Continuum.

  • Observation and Conference Forms are designed to support administrators in the process of observing and providing feedback to teachers. These forms guide the supervisor to collect evidence and analyze the information collected during the observation, providing suggestions on how to offer feedback, ask questions, and develop a plan to improve future instruction of the science practices.   

  • Example lessons designed to help promote learning and application of the 8 science practices, spanning various grades and science topics. The site includes 3 types of example lessons: Text-Based, Video, and Lesson Adaptation case studies. The example lessons can be used as part of a conference or professional development in which teachers identify the target science practices before examining the commentary on the website.

  • Lesson Adaptations, which are case studies are intended to provide examples of classroom instruction using the science practices. Each case study offers four variations of a lesson to be ordered along the Continuum for a particular science practice. These case studies aim to provide educators with instances of the key levers for each practice on the Continuum and to serve as a resource to adapt current lessons.

  • Web-Based Application, which functions as a web-based set of supervision tools to gather evidence from observations and share feedback with teachers.


Throughout the project, we continued to develop and refine the tools and resources described above. After creating an initial set of tools, we conducted a series of observations and collaborative meetings with 4 principals who worked intensively with us on the refinement of the tools. We also facilitated a set of 3 professional development workshops with 25 K-8 principals  during which we drew on the ILSP tools to train the instructional leaders in supervision for the science practices. In addition to the tools and online resources for principals’ use in supervision, we developed a survey instrument to measure the Leadership Content Knowledge for the Science Practices (LCK-SP). Engaging in a process of piloting and revision, we created a refined survey. We used this survey as a pre- and post- assessment for principals participating in the professional development workshop we ran as a way to train principals in the ILSP tools.


Our research has yielded a set of research findings about the supervision of science practices in K-8 schools. We have demonstrated that using these resources, principals were more likely to use the lens of science practices to examine classroom instruction (Lowenhaupt & McNeill, 2018). Furthermore, principals’ experienced significant gains in their beliefs and knowledge of the science practices after participating in professional development using the resources (McNeill, Lowenhaupt, Cherbow & Lowell, in preparation). Our work has been taken up widely by principals, district science coordinators, and teachers working on implementing the science practices. We have disseminated the work at national conferences for practitioners and academics (e.g. NARST and AERA), through webinars with state science directors in more than 20 states, and locally through networks of principals, training for aspiring principals, and science coordinators. We have also written about the project in a series of academic peer-reviewed journal articles and practitioner journals.
